                AP Photo

            By 
Daniel Strauss

09/02/15, 02:46 PM EDT
In the wake of debate rules changes announced Tuesday, the Republican National Committee convened a conference call Wednesday morning to brief campaigns on logistics and the effect of the new debate criteria.
The call, designed to prevent grumbling from the GOP presidential campaigns and answer questions about the upcoming debate, came less than a day after another conference call -- convened by CNN -- announced rules changes that opened the door for Carly Fiorina to appear in the Sept. 16 primetime debate.
The two calls come as Republican and CNN officials try to accommodate an unusually large 17-candidate primary field while also responding to concerns that Fiorina might not make the stage for the primetime debate because of the polling threshold. The lone woman in the field, Fiorina's standing in the polls has increased in the wake of a strong performance in the Aug. 6 undercard debate. But the former Hewlett-Packard CEO was in danger of being excluded from the next primetime debate because of the timeframe of the established polling criteria -- and CNN and the RNC were under increasing pressure to find a way to include her on the stage.
Under the changes revealed Tuesday, Fiorina would likely make the cut: CNN announced that it would allow any candidate who ranked in the top 10 between the last debate on Aug. 6 and Sept. 10 into the primetime debate.
According to multiple campaign operatives who were on the Tuesday CNN call announcing the new rules, no campaign representatives voiced disagreement about the rules change but there were conflicting accounts as to whether that was because the floor for that call was not opened up to ask questions or whether campaign operatives on the call simply didn't pipe up. The discussion then turned to debate details such as the number of spin rooms and the amount of space available for supporters at the venue.
"They went through all the logistics but on the front end, and again they delayed the call, it was supposed to be at 1 and they moved it to 5," one top operative of a Republican campaign said of the Tuesday call. "And they said 'we're going to read a statement from CNN and we will not be taking questions or comments about this statement and that's where they then read the statement about the rules change and there was no opportunity. They were not going to allow anyone to comment -- express pleasure, displeasure about that."
Campaign operatives who were on both calls described the Wednesday RNC conference call as the latest in its series of alternating calls going over logistics about the next debate. Those calls happen every other week and had been scheduled in advance of Tuesday's news -- a reflection of the urgency and pressure organizers feel in making sure campaigns feel looped into debate planning. The call, which lasted about 10 minutes, was solely about logistical aspects of the next debate -- such as ticketing.



            By 
Nick Gass

RNC chief strategist and communications director Sean Spicer said Wednesday the line was open to participants on the call and nobody asked questions in response to the announcement. The discussion then quickly moved to Sept. 16 debate logistics.
"Throughout the call probably at least seven different people voiced at different times like 'hey, hold on a second,' or 'can you explain further, that's going to be a problem,'" Spicer said, adding that after the announcement that "there was a pause" and "all the lines were open" but nobody asked questions on the announcement.
Even so, some campaigns were frustrated by the timing of the two calls and questioned why there wasn't just one long call to go over logistics questions and also discuss the rules change.
"So why don't you just do this all at once?" a chief strategist for a Republican presidential campaign on the call said. "But my guess is they didn't want to make this announcement to everybody and then have a longer call where people could start airing their grievances."
The cable networks, Spicer explained, are given the option to either pick their own date to hold a call or to simply piggyback on the bi-weekly call. Going forward, he said, there could be one big call to go over debate criteria and also answer questions from both the RNC and the network cohosting the debate.
Katie Glueck and Hadas Gold contributed to this report.

                                            By 
Nicholas Carr


                                            By 
Jeff Smith


                                            By 
Philip Gordon


                                            By 
Michael Kazin

title: The RNC's multiple debate calls
